title: Synthetic Recap
body:
PHILADELPHIA (AP) — They came to see the league’s MVP, but they witnessed the coronation of a king. On a night when the Philadelphia 76ers honored Allen Iverson, the Sacramento Kings’ Mitch Richmond staged a breathtaking offensive clinic, pouring in a career-high 47 points to power Sacramento to a stunning 107-92 rout on the road.

From the opening tip, Richmond was uncontainable. He was a force of nature, slicing through the lane, pulling up from mid-range, and draining threes with a cold-blooded efficiency that left the Sixers’ defense, and the entire Spectrum, in a state of disbelief. Every time Philadelphia threatened to build momentum, Richmond had an answer, a silky-smooth jumper that silenced the crowd and extended the lead.

His 47-point explosion wasn't just volume; it was historic artistry. He shot a blistering 71% from the field, a staggering number for a guard, and was a perfect 12-of-12 from the free-throw line. This was a masterclass in scoring, a performance so dominant it overshadowed everything else on the court.

While Iverson managed 25 points, he was rendered a secondary character in Richmond’s one-man show. The Kings’ supporting cast, led by Corliss Williamson’s 15 points, provided just enough support, but this night belonged to one man.

In the end, the final score was almost an afterthought. The real story was the virtuoso performance by Mitch Richmond, who on this night in Philadelphia, wasn’t just the best player on the floor—he was utterly untouchable. It was a career-defining masterpiece that announced, unequivocally, his place among the game’s elite scorers.
